metadata.title: New Frontiers: The Origins and Content of New Work, 1940-2018

relevance.topic: The role of newly emerging job categories in counterbalancing the effects of automation on labor demand.
relevance.relevance: The study is highly relevant as it examines the emergence of new work categories in response to technological changes, which is directly related to labor displacement due to technological change.

historical_context.economic_conditions: Post-World War II economic expansion and subsequent technological advancements.
historical_context.institutional_context: U.S. labor market policies and economic conditions from 1940 to 2018.

outcomes.main_findings: The majority of current employment is in new job specialties introduced since 1940. New work emerges in response to technological innovations that complement the outputs of occupations and demand shocks that raise occupational demand.
outcomes.conclusions: Augmentation innovations boost occupational labor demand while automation innovations erode it. The demand-eroding effects of automation innovations have intensified in the past four decades while the demand-increasing effects of augmentation innovations have not.

quality_assessment.methodological_limitations: The study relies on historical data and patent analysis, which may not capture all nuances of technological impacts on labor.
quality_assessment.coherence: The study provides a coherent analysis of the relationship between technological innovations and labor demand.
quality_assessment.adequacy_of_data: The data spans eight decades and includes a comprehensive analysis of new job titles and patent data.
quality_assessment.relevance: The study is highly relevant to understanding the impact of technological change on labor markets.
